title: Artificial intelligence research has a slop problem, academics say: ‘It’s a mess’
description:
AI research in question as author claims to have written over 100 papers on AI that one expert calls a ‘disaster’
A single person claims to have authored 113 academic papers on artificial intelligence this year, 89 of which will be presented this week at one of the world’s leading conference on AI and machine learning, which has raised questions among computer scientists about the state of AI research.
The author, Kevin Zhu, recently finished a bachelor’s degree in computer science at the University of California, Berkeley, and now runs Algoverse, an AI research and mentoring company for high schoolers – many of whom are his co-authors on the papers. Zhu himself graduated from high school in 2018.
 Continue reading...

title: Oklahoma High School Football: No. 20 Bixby wins eighth straight state championship
description: For the eighth consecutive year in a row, the Bixby Spartans will be an Oklahoma high school football state champion. Though unlike their high-scoring selves, the Spartans had to hold off an upset-minded Owasso group to hold on for the 24-17 win to nab the Oklahoma Secondary School Activities Association (OHSAA) state championship at the University of Central […]

title: Siena University Lacrosse Coach Dies at 41 After Traumatic Brain Injury from Fall: 'A Sudden, Senseless Loss'
description: Liam Gleason fell in his home, leading to the fatal injury

title: Michael Dell's journey to a $148 billion fortune began with a $1,000 investment
description: Dell founded his computer company in 1984 while a student at University of Texas. He had just $1,000 to start with.

title: Charlie Kirk tops Wikipedia’s list of most-read articles in 2025
description:
Zohran Mamdani, Ozzy Osbourne and Sinners also feature in encyclopedia’s top 20 most-read English-language pages
Wikipedia’s article on Charlie Kirk was the most read on the online encyclopedia this year, as users sought out information on the conservative activist.
People viewed the entry on Kirk nearly 45m times, many after he was shot at a university campus debate on 10 September.
Charlie Kirk, 44.9m page views
Deaths in 2025, 42.5m
Ed Gein, 31.

title: Oregon's hospital price cap cut costs without comprising care
description: A Brown University School of Public Health analysis shows Oregon’s cap on hospital payments for the state employee health plan led to major savings without reducing services, staffing or patient satisfaction.

title: America has the tools to heal division: we need to relearn them
description: Governance scholar and University of Pittsburgh professor Jennifer Brick Murtazashvili, Ph.D. on the forces that decide whether conflicted nations unify or unravel.

title: I'm a 22-year-old university student building an AI startup. The hardest part is losing student life.
description: A 22-year-old cybersecurity student shares what it's like to build an AI startup in university, and why being a young founder can feel lonely.

title: Northwestern will pay Trump admin $75 million to settle antisemitism cases and restore funding while agreeing to ‘socialize international students’
description: The Trump administration had frozen $790 million in grants that contributed to university layoffs and the resignation of the university's president in September.

title: Southern University hires Marshall Faulk as next head coach
description: Pro Football Hall of Famer Marshall Faulk has parlayed one year of college coaching as an assistant into a head-coaching job.

title: Louisiana closes out west coast trip at UC Davis
description: The Louisiana Ragin’ Cajuns Men’s Basketball team closes out its three-game trip to the West Coast on Monday when it faces UC Davis at the University Credit Union Center.

title: ‘We could have asked ChatGPT’: students fight back over course taught by AI
description:
Staffordshire students say signs material was AI-generated included suspicious file names and rogue voiceover accent
Students at the University of Staffordshire have said they feel “robbed of knowledge and enjoyment” after a course they hoped would launch their digital careers turned out to be taught in large part by AI.
James and Owen were among 41 students who took a coding module at Staffordshire last year, hoping to change careers through a government-funded apprenticeship programme designed to help them become cybersecurity experts or software engineers.
 Continue reading...

title: Consumers Frustrated With High Prices, Jobs a Concern: UMich's Hsu
description: "Consumers are still worried that things are going to get worse before they get better," University of Michigan Surveys of Consumers Director Joanne Hsu says. Speaking on "Bloomberg Open Interest," Hsu says US consumers remain frustrated about the persistence of high prices and perceive labor markets as weakening.
